questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft Excel file that includes journal entry data that must be imported into Dynamics 365 Business Central. This file was previously imported into a
General Journal batch.
You receive an updated version of the file that includes corrections, deletions, and new journal entries.
Which two actions can you perform by using the Edit in Excel feature? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.B: Insert a new line in a General Journal batch
choices.D: Request Approval for one or more lines in a General Journal batch
choices.A: Modify an existing line in a General Journal batch
choices.E: Delete an existing line from a General Journal batch
choices.C: Post one or more lines in a General Journal batch

discussion.content: Deletion, modification and insertion can all be done using Edit in Excel, so not sure why B is excluded and it only asks for two options.
I agree with the more recent comments, you can now delete, modify and insert using the Edit in Excel feature.
According to this post, B is not doable. https://community.dynamics.com/forums/thread/details/?threadid=6553650d-0cce-4c4f-98a1-ee67a5b1af11

comments.content: In my opinion B is also possible. maybe it has been adjusted?

discussion.content: do we know if the answer is still true or if the answer now is ABE? and the question changed to be asking for 3 questions? as looking at the answers this question is at least 2 Years old and might have been adjusted ?

Selected Answer: AB
It must also be correct

Selected Answer: AB
E is correct too
Not sure if I have a newer version of BC, but I am able to do all 3 in my payment batch: Modify, Insert, and Delete. You must hit "refresh" before "publish" to make sure all records are in sync.

With only two options available it should be:
A. Modify an existing line in a General Journal batch 
E. Delete an existing line from a General Journal batch 

If you go to "General Journals" --> Page --> Edit in Excel

I could successfully delete and modifiy (e.g. date). New lines (duplicated) could not be published to BC.
On exam question only asks for two options.

To report profitability by business line in Dynamics 365 Business Central, you need to configure dimensions to track financial transactions by business line. Hereâ€™s how you should set up the system:

- Create a dimension: Choose "Business Line" as the dimension, which will enable you to tag transactions according to the different business lines.

- Assign the dimension: Set this dimension to be used with "G/L Account" because profitability is often tracked through general ledger entries that reflect income and expenses associated with each business line.

- Select a value posting: Choose "Code Mandatory" to ensure that every financial transaction tagged with the "Business Line" dimension must have a value. This ensures complete data for accurate profitability reporting.
Think it should be dimension 'value'

comments.content:
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-gb/dynamics365/business-central/finance-dimensions
Account type default Dim is correct. 
"To set up default dimensions for customers, suppliers, and other accounts:
On the Dimensions page, select the relevant dimension, then choose the Account Type Default Dim action."

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You need to report profitability by business line.
How should you configure the system? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

comments.content: You are correct. This is the way.
ok , i had check this in Cronus again it's going correct
But they are talking about Customer Source should be on every transaction , if you we setup default dimension Customer table then it can cause issue i think
Default dimension does not mean to set default value... Just leave it empty. i have test on cronus and it works. i assume that the solution provided by bcws is correct
I think the same. Your answer is correct
I agree. It doesn't seem correct to me neither. I would have answered as you did.

discussion.content:
The answer doesn't seem correct. Step 2 from COA does not flow logically to step 3, as the the Account Type Default Dimension is not opened from COA. If the answer is trying to assign specific Default Dimension Value against specific G/L Account, then step 3 should be "open Default Dimensions and select the customer source dimension code", which is not an option.

My answer would be:
1. Create a dimension code to identify the customer source
2. Create dimension values for the customer source dimension code
3. From the Dimension Code, select the Account Type Default Dimension list
4. Add the Customer table
5. Set the Value Posting to Code Mandatory

However, imo step 2 is not specifically related to the requirement but five options are needed then this is the best option, which could be done as second step or the last step.

I concure with the answers given here. going to Chart of Accounts makes no sense. 
hence 
1. Create a dimension code to identify the customer source
2. Create dimension values for the customer source dimension code
3. From the Dimension Code, select the Account Type Default Dimension list
4. Add the Customer table
5. Set the Value Posting to Code Mandatory

I disagree with bcws in the assesment that set 2 is not needed though. As not setting up values with "code Mandatory" will make it impossible to post anything as no Code can be added into a field that requires a Code

I agree with the BCWS' answer.
1. Create a dimension code to identify the customer source
2. Create dimension values for the customer source dimension code
3. From the Dimension Code, select the Account Type Default Dimension list
4. Add the Customer table
5. Set the Value Posting to Code Mandatory

I think the answer is:

1. Create a dimension code to identify the customer source
2. Create dimension values for the customer source dimension code
3. From the Dimension Code, select the Account Type Default Dimension list
4. Add the Customer table
5. Set the Value Posting to Code Mandatory
agree with bcws

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You need to ensure that any transaction that uses a customer account always includes the customer source dimension.
Which five actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

You need to configure the new customer creation process.
Which two areas must you configure? Each correct answer presents part of the solution
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
The correct answers are:

C. Configuration template
D. Permissions

Here's a brief explanation of each:

C. Configuration template: Configuration templates in Dynamics 365 Business Central can be used to streamline the process of creating new customers. You can set up a template with common settings and then use that template each time you create a new customer. This can help ensure consistency and accuracy in your customer data.

D. Permissions: You'll also need to configure permissions to ensure that only authorized users can create new customers. In Dynamics 365 Business Central, you can set up permission sets that define what actions a user or group of users can perform. You can then assign these permission sets to your users.

The other options (A: Responsibility center and B: Configuration worksheet) are not typically used for configuring the new customer creation process in Dynamics 365 Business Central.

Selected Answer: CD
correct
C,D is correct.

Selected Answer: CD
D is required

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You need to design a process to resolve the broker issues for Accounts.
Which three actions should perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
NOTE: More than one order of answer choices is correct. You will receive credit for any of the correct orders you select.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: correct answer is also 1.create nr. series 2.define nr series line 3. relationship

The answer is correct however assuming the following typos:
- In the second point it should beâ€šVendor Templateâ€˜. â€žData Templateâ€œ does not exist or at least I cannot find it in BC.
- In third point it also should beâ€žVendor Templateâ€œ, as it is a logic consequence. A â€žConfiguration Templateâ€œ wouldnâ€™t work with No. Series the way it can be done with â€žVendor Templateâ€œ. So the correct order:

- Create a No. Series
- Create a Vendor Template
- Define the No. Series on the Vendor Template.

It's correct, the scenario says: "Adding new brokers is a different process than adding other purchase vendors. Users often forget which fields to select and how to correctly assign the vendor number to add new brokers." 

To overcome user forgetting which field to select, we need a configuration template,
To overcome the issue with correctly assign the vendor number to add new broker, you need to create a no. series. You can then assign that no. series on the Vendor Template or Customer Template card. I tried to look into the Configuration Template card but I couldn't find the "No. Series" field. But the field is actually in the Vendor Template card.
It's said "more than one order is correct". Which is the other one?

comments.content: anche la risposta corretta Ã¨ 1.create nr. serie 2.define nr linea di serie 3. relazione

discussion.content: Shouldn't "Define No. Series Line" be a part of the sequence?
It's correct
